Effect of internal and external electron donors on stereospecific polymerization of isoprene with TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts Qingtao Niu Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Formal analysis Validation Funding acquisition a Aihua He Methodology Funding acquisition b Chongdian Si Funding acquisition a Guodong Liu Funding acquisition a Bolin Dai Resources Investigation a Manman Jin Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a School of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials, Jining University, Qufu, Shandong 273155, China School of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Jining University Qufu Shandong 273155 China aSchool of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials, Jining University, Qufu, Shandong 273155, China b Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization, Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education), School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, Shandong 266042, China Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization, Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education), School of Polymer Science and Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao Shandong 266042 China bShandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization, Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education), School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, Shandong 266042, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Two TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts containing ethyl benzoate (EB) and dibutyl phthalate (DBP) as internal electron donors (ID) were prepared for isoprene polymerizations using five kinds of external electron donors (ED) (phenyltrimethoxysilane (ED-1), dicyclopentyl(dimethoxy)silane (ED-2), 2-butyl-2-ethyl-1,3-dimethoxypropane (ED-3), 1,3-dimethoxypropane (ED-4) and di(2-ethylhexyl)phthalate (ED-5)). The structure features of TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalysts were characterized and the effect of ID and ED on polymerization behaviors was studied. EB had higher adsorption content on catalyst surface, higher catalytic activity and lower trans-1,4 stereoselectivity than DBP. Appropriate introduction of ED-1 and ED-2, expect ED-3, ED-4 and ED-5, caused the enhancement in polymerization activity and trans-1,4 content, while excess addition led to the deactivation. The effect of ED on equilibrium between selective activation and deactivation of active species significantly relied on the electron donor type and concentration. Graphical abstract The internal and external electron donors play significant roles in catalytic activity and stereoselectivity of TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts for isoprene polymerizations. Internal electron donor EB with small molecular size had higher adsorption ability on support surface and higher catalytic activity than that of DBP which gave polymers with higher trans-1,4 content and M w. Appropriate external electron donors alkoxysilanes, except esters and benzoate, had activation effect on polymerization, thus raising the catalytic activity and polymers trans-1,4 content. Parallelly, excess addition of external electron donors led to the deactivation of active species. The reversible equilibrium effect between selective activation and partial deactivation significantly relied on the concentration and molecular type of external electron donor. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Internal electron donor External electron donor TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst Isoprene Stereospecific polymerization Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Heterogeneous TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts have become the most dominant industrial catalysts for commercial manufacture of trans-1,4 polydiene materials [1–5]. However, precise understandings of active species nature and stereoselectivity mechanism of isoprene polymerization, especially for special roles of electron donors, are still great challenges due to the TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts features with multisite, trace titanium content, easy deactivation, complex reactions among active center precursor, alkylaluminium and supports [6–10]. In industrial practice of olefin polymerization, TiCl4/MgCl2 Ziegler-Natta catalysts, dominantly consisting of activated MgCl2 support, TiCl4 as active center precursor and alkylaluminum cocatalyst, are mainly prepared by the traditional mechanical ball-milling routes and modern chemical routes [11–20]. The mechanical routs are based on the co-milling of regular crystalline α-MgCl2 and TiCl4 to complete the activation of MgCl2 (defective δ-MgCl2) supports and loading of Ti species, and the chemical routes utilize the chemical transformation from MgCl2 precursor into highly defective and activated δ-MgCl2 and subsequently contact with TiCl4. In order to improve catalytic performances (activity and stereoselectivity) of TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts, organic electron donors are widely added during the catalyst preparation and olefin polymerization processes [21–30]. Electron donor introduced during the preparation process of TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst is named as internal electron donor (ID), and that added in olefin polymerization is called as external electron donor (ED). Suitable combinations of ID and ED can achieve high catalytic activity and stereoselectivity, e.g. the most effective TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst uses dialkyl phthalate as ID and alkoxysilane as ED in current industrial production of isotactic polypropylene [31,32]. For the olefins polymerization with TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts, ID and ED have great influences on catalytic behaviors including support structure, polymerization activity, microstructure, M w of polymer and so on [33–46]. Cavallo et al. [33] and Taniike et al. [34] reported that IDs (1,3-diethers, dibutyl phthalate) added during catalyst preparation significantly facilitated a substantial reconstruction as well as growth of MgCl2, adsorbed in proximity of Ti species and improve the stereoselectivity of TiCl4/MgCl2 Ziegler-Natta catalyst, owing to a steric modulation of active specie surroundings. Stukalov et al. [35] using diffusive reflection infrared spectroscopy and analytical techniques found that the molecule size of ID strongly influenced ID adsorption on MgCl2 surface and coadsorption with TiCl4 which occupied dominantly the complexation sites that were inaccessible for ID due to steric reasons. In 1-hexene polymerization catalyzed by MgCl2-supported catalyst, Fan et al. [36] revealed that both diethylphthalate and anisole used as internal electron donor greatly reduced the active center number, enhanced active center reactivity and generated medium to high molecular weight parts. Chadwick et al. [37] reported that diether donor generated narrow M w/M n while the combination of phthalate ester and alkoxysilane formed high M w because of the origin of electron donor adsorption in the surrounding environment of active species. Active site models corresponding to the actions of electron donors in olefins polymerization using Ziegler-Natta catalysts have also been widely reported [38–40]. To date, it is well accepted that the three-site model presents the reversible equilibrium transformation among the aspecific species, syndiospecific species and highly isopecific species [41,42]. The electron donor can convert the aspecific site into the isospecific site through the successive adsorption on catalyst surface, promote the increase in the numbers of isospecific sites and generate higher isosoecific sites [43]. Fan et al. [44] found that alkoxysilanes used as the ED in propylene polymerization either complexed with active specie Ti and adjacent Mg atom, causing the deactivation of active species, or complexed with two adjacent Mg atoms, leading to the activation of active sites. ED can also has the coadsorption with alkylaluminum on catalyst surface leading to enhancement in surface coverage and steric hindrance of active sites [45,46]. Although enormous theoretical and experimental studies have been done to explore the actions of electron donors in α-olefin polymerizations, the influence of internal electron donor as well as external electron donor on isoprene polymerization using heterogeneous TiCl4/MgCl2 Ziegler-Natta catalyst are scarcely reported. In this paper, ethyl benzoate and dibutyl phthalate were added in the catalyst preparation process to chemically synthesize TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 Ziegler-Natta catalyst, and five kinds of ED were added during the isoprene polymerization. The effect of internal and external electron donor on catalytic behaviors including catalyst structure, polymerization activity, microstructure and molecular weight of polymers were investigated for the first time. The stereospecific nature of active sites in TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalyst corresponding to the special roles of internal and external electron donors was discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Mg powder (200 mesh, 99.8%) was purchased from Shandong AEX Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. 1-Chlorobutane (98%, dried over 4A molecular sieves) and iodine (I2, 99.99%, used as halide initiator) were purchased by Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4, 99%) was supplied by Shanghai Macklin Biochenical Co., Ltd. Ethyl benzoate (EB, >99%), dibutyl phthalate (DBP, 99%), Phenyltrimethoxysilane (ED-1, >98%) and dicyclopentyl(dimethoxy)silane (ED-2, >98%) were supplied by Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2-Butyl-2-ethyl-1,3-dimethoxypropane (ED-3, 97%) was supplied by Beijing J&K Scientific Ltd. 1,3-dimethoxypropane (ED-4, 97%) and di(2-ethylhexyl)phthalate (ED-5, 99%) were supplied by Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Isoprene (>99%, supplied by Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd) was first purified through a chromatography column containing chromatographic silica gel, alkaline alumina and anhydrous potassium carbon, then dried over CaH2 for 24 h and finally distilled before use. Triisobutylaluminum (Al(i-Bu)3, 3.9 mol/L) was supplied by Yanshan Petrochemical Co., Ltd, China. Xylene, n-heptane and n-octane were first dried over 4A molecular sieves and then purified by Na/benzophenone. 2.2 Preparation of support and catalyst MgCl2 support was prepared based on the reaction between Mg powder and 1-chlorobutane [47,48,16]. Briefly, 520.0 mL n-octane, 17.5 g Mg powder, 163.0 mL 1-chlorobutane and 0.045 g I2 were sequentially introduced into a 2000 mL round-bottom flask and reacted for 2 h at 120 °C under the refluxing condition at -10 °C. After being cooled down to the room temperature, the resulted solid powder was washed times by n-octane and dried at 60 °C under vacuum for 24 h. Under a N2 atmosphere, TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalysts were prepared as followed: (1) TiCl4/EB/MgCl2 catalyst (Cat-1): n-heptane (107.4 mL), MgCl2 powder (21.49 g) and TiCl4 (0.0045 mol) were added into a three-necked flask bearing a magnetic stirrer and reacted at 60 °C for 1 h, then 3.42 g EB ([EB]:[Mg] = 0.1:1) was added into the flask, continuing to react for another 1 h at the same temperature. After being cooled down to room temperature, the catalyst powder was washed times by n-heptane and dried at 45 °C under vacuum for 24 h. (2) TiCl4/DBP/MgCl2 catalyst (Cat-2): n-heptane (111.4 mL), MgCl2 powder (22.27 g) and TiCl4 (0.0046 mol) were added into a three-necked flask containing a magnetic stirrer and reacted at 60 °C for 1h, then 6.57 g DBP ([DBP]:[Mg] = 0.1:1) was added into flask, continuing to react for 1 h at the same temperature. After being cooled down to the room temperature, the catalyst powder was washed times by n-heptane and dried at 45 °C under vacuum for 24 h. 2.3 Isoprene polymerization Series of polymerizations of isoprene were performed in 100 round-bottom flasks containing magnetic stirrers. Calculated amounts of isoprene (44.6 wt% in xylene), Al(i-Bu)3, and external electron donor (when need) were successively introduced into the purged flasks. Polymerizations were initiated at 30 °C by the addition of TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalyst powders. After a certain reaction time, alcohol /concentrated HCl (98/2, v/v) mixture was added into the flasks to terminate polymerizations. The resulted polymers were washed times by excess alcohol, and dried at 45 °C under vacuum for 24 h. 2.4 Characterization The titanium and magnesium content of catalyst was measured by the inductively coupled argon plasma (ICP) analysis with an OPTIMA 2100 DV optical emission spectroscopy spectrometer. The chlorine content of catalyst was characterized by the ion chromatography (ThermoFisher IC-5000+). The content of ID in catalysts was characterized by an Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was carried out using a Rint 2000 vertical goniometer with Cu Kα radiation. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrums were characterized with a spectrometer (HGCS20170343J) using KBr pellet technique. Polymer structures were analyzed according to the 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR spectra, which were characterized by a Bruker spectrometer (100 MHz) with chloroform-d (CDCl3) using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as standard at 25 °C. M w as well as M w/M n of polymer was measured by a HLC-8320GPC gel permeation chromatography with tetrahydrofuran (THF) at 45 °C and calibrated by polystyrene standards. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structure features of TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalysts MgCl2 supports were prepared based on the chemical reaction between 1-chlorobutane and metallic Mg powders, then treated with TiCl4 and internal electron donors forming the TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalysts. The powder X-ray diffraction pattern, FT-IR spectra and corresponding results were presented in Fig. 1 as well as Table 1 . Fig. 1(a) showed that the activated MgCl2 supports showed broad diffraction peaks centered at 2θ = 15.8° (003), 32.3° (006) and 50.0° (110). The (003) peak was attributed to the stacking of the Cl-Mg-Cl layer at crystallographic direction, and (006) and (110) peaks were corresponded to the stacking faults of the layers [17,47,48]. The diffraction patterns with these peaks corresponded to the δ-MgCl2 with disordered structure. After the coadsorption of TiCl4 and ID (EB and DBP), the TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalysts well preserved the crystal structure integrity. FT-IR spectrums (Fig. 1(b)) showed a sharp and intense absorption band at 1633 cm−1 as well as two weaker bands centered at 2250 cm−1 and 1853 cm−1, which were assigned to the v(Mg-Cl) vibrations. Two absorption bands at 613 cm−1 and 472 cm−1 were attributed to v(Ti-Cl) vibrations of precursors, indicating the coordination of Ti species on surface of catalysts [47,49], and the Mg, Cl, Ti contents of Cat-1 and Cat-2 were 27.5 wt%, 59.5 wt%, 0.85 wt% and 24.4 wt%, 62.0 wt%, 0.84 wt% (Table 1), respectively. The absorption bands in the region of 1745∼1710 cm−1 belonged to the carbonyl stretching vibrations (v(C=O)) of the complexed internal electron donors EB or DBP on the surface of supports [35]. Gas chromatograph characterization showed that the EB and DBP contents of catalysts were 0.66 mmol/(g⋅cat) and 0.08 mmol/(g⋅cat) (Table 1), respectively, which indicated that EB with small molecular size had higher adsorption ability than that of DBP with large molecular size. The activated MgCl2 supports had irregularly stacked Cl-Mg-Cl sandwiches, which were composed of the coordinatively saturated (001) lateral cuts as well as the unsaturated (104) and (110) lateral cuts [50–52]. The chemisorption of EB and DBP occurred only on the (104) and (110) lateral cuts. For further investigation of the distributions of ID complexation on MgCl2 surfaces, the absorption bands of v(C=O) were resolved in two fitting peaks (Fig. 1(c) and (d)) [35,53,54]. The high-frequency bands at 1735∼1730 cm−1 were assigned to the complexation of ID on (104) MgCl2, and the low-frequency bands at 1720∼1710 cm−1 were assigned to the complexation of ID on (110) MgCl2 [35]. The deconvolutions (Fig. 1(c) and (d) and Table 1) showed that the coordination of ID with penta-coordinated Mg atoms on (104) obviously prevailed over that with tetra-coordinated Mg atoms on (110), owing to the relatively low surface energy of (104) MgCl2 plane [55]. Considering the coordination effect on the supports surface, chemisorption of ID on (110) MgCl2 were more stable and flexible than that on (104) lateral cuts [56–60]. On the (110) MgCl2 surface, the more compact coordination of a molecule EB or DBP with one Mg atom through the two oxygen atoms was more preferential (Fig. 1(e)) [35]. 3.2 Isoprene polymerization behaviors with TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalysts The Cat-1 and Cat-2 catalysts were subjected to series of isoprene polymerizations using Al(i-Bu)3 as cocatalyst. The dependence of catalytic behaviors (catalytic activity, polymers cis-1,4/trans-1,4 unit content, dyad sequence, unit linkage, M w and M w/M n) on polymerization time (2∼60 min), ID type and alkylaluminum concentration were investigated. The results were showed in Table 2 , Figs. 2 and 3 . As seen from Table 2 and Fig. 2, with the increasing polymerization time from 2 min to 60 min, the monomer conversion of TiCl4/EB/MgCl2 catalyst increased gradually from 0.13 wt% to 1.65 wt%, and the catalytic activity presented a quick enhancement to the maximum value (690 g⋅P/(g⋅Ti⋅h)) at 2 min and then decreased slowly. The similar activity tendency had also been reported in traditional TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst prepared by mechanical ball-milling routes for isoprene and butadiene copolymerization [3]. The microstructure of polymers synthesized in the early stage of polymerization was cis-1,4 and trans-1,4 mixed structure, then the cis-1,4 content gradually reduced while trans-1,4 content significantly increased and finally became the main structure for polymers, which indicated the stereoselective change of active sites during the polymerization process[1–3]. The dyad sequence and unit linkage of polymer chain with time were analyzed by the 13C-NMR spectra [2,3]. As shown in Fig. 3, polymers obtained in the early stage of 10 min had 17.9 mol% trans-1,4-[II] and 82.1 mol% cis-1,4-[II] dyad sequence concentration, and 18.1 mol% trans-trans and 81.2 mol% cis-cis unit linkage content. With the increasing polymerization time, the trans-1,4-[II] dyad sequence and trans-trans unit linkage content gradually increased, while the cis-1,4-[II] dyad sequence and cis-cis unit linkage content decreased. The cis-trans unit linkage content of polymer chains were in the range of 0.7∼2.2 mol%. These phenomena indicated the coexistence of trans-1,4 and cis-1,4 sequence in one polymer chain, and the trans-1,4 sequence length gradually increased as polymerization time increased. Alkylaluminum also had great importance on polymerization behaviors. As the alkylaluminum concentration increased from Al/Ti = 50 mol/mol to Al/Ti = 100 mol/mol in TiCl4/EB/MgCl2 catalyst system, the isoprene conversion and polymerization activity increased from 1.65 wt% and 294 g⋅P/(g⋅Ti⋅h) to 2.53 wt% and 450 g⋅P/(g⋅Ti⋅h) (Fig. 2(e)), respectively, and the trans-1,4 structure content and M w of polymers also enhanced from 55.3 mol% and 3.8 × 105 to 69.3 mol% and 4.5 × 105. The trans-1,4-[II] dyad sequence and trans-trans unit linkage content also raised from 17.9 mol% and 18.1 mol% to 64.9 mol% and 64.4 mol% (Fig. 3(c)∼(d)), respectively. These results were attributed to the effect of alkylaluminum concentration on active centers formation and stereoselectivity transformation [1]. When dibutyl phthalate was used as internal electron donor, the TiCl4/DBP/MgCl2 catalyst exhibited greatly higher trans-1,4 structure content (84.1 mol%) and higher M w (4.7 × 105) while relatively lower polymerization activity comparing with that of TiCl4/EB/MgCl2 catalyst. The phenomenon revealed that the influence of internal electron donors on TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts significantly relied on the steric hindrance of active sites. Dibutyl phthalate with larger groups coordinated on the surface of catalyst and generated higher steric surroundings of active sites, in turn improving the trans-1,4 stereoselectivity of Ti species while reducing the catalytic activity. 3.3 Effect of ED on polymerization behavior For the further investigation of the effect of electron donors on nature of active species, five kinds of external electron donors including phenyltrimethoxysilane (ED-1), dicyclopentyl(dimethoxy)silane (ED-2), 2-butyl-2-ethyl-1,3-dimethoxypropane (ED-3), 1,3-dimethoxypropane (ED-4) and di(2-ethylhexyl)phthalate (ED-5) were added in the isoprene polymerization using TiCl4/EB/MgCl2 catalyst at 30 min. The influence of ED on polymerization activity, polymer microstructure, M w and M w/M n was summarized in Table 3 and Fig. 4 . Appropriate introduction of alkoxysilanes (ED-1 and ED-2, ED/Ti = 0.1∼0.3 mol/mol) promoted the enhancement in monomer conversion and catalytic activity from 0.95 wt% and 337 g⋅P/(g⋅Ti⋅h) to 1.05 wt% and 375 g⋅P/(g⋅Ti⋅h) (Fig. 4(a) and (b)), respectively, and polymers trans-1,4 structure content and M w also increased from 35.4 mol% and 6.9 × 105 to 37.5 mol% and 7.8 × 105, respectively. Conversely, introduction of ethers (ED-3 and ED-4) and benzoate (ED-5) caused relatively decrease in polymerization activity, polymers trans-1,4 structure content and M w. The phenomenon demonstrated that alkoxysilanes used as external electron donors had activation effect on active sites in combination of ethyl benzoate as internal electron donor in TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst for isoprene polymerization. Similar activation effect had also been reported in production of isotactic polypropylene [31,32]. When further increasing the ED concentration up to ED/Ti = 1 mol/mol, five external electron donors all presented obvious decrease in monomer conversion, catalytic activity, polymers trans-1,4 structure content and M w, which revealed that excess addition of ED caused partly deactivation effect on isoprene polymerization regardless of the type of external electron donors. The effect of ED on equilibrium between selective activation and deactivation of active species significantly relied on the electron donor type and concentration. 3.4 Plausible mechanisms of trans-1,4 stereoslectivity of TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst Considering the stable adsorption of TiCl4 and electron donors on MgCl2 (110) lateral cuts, and the influence of ID and ED on isoprene polymerization behaviors, possible stereospecific models of TiCl4/ID/MgCl2-Al(i-Bu)3/ED catalyst system were showed in Scheme 1 . After being added during the TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst preparation process, benzoate internal electron donors coordinated with Mg atoms in the proximity of TiCl4 on MgCl2 support surface through two oxygen atoms. Active species C*-1 bearing low steric hindrance, low trans-1,4 stereoselectivity as well as easy chain transfer were first generated based on the alkylation and reduction reaction between TiCl4 and Al(i-Bu)3. C*-1 gave the generation of cis-1,4 units of polymers with low M w causing the high cis-1,4 content in the beginning of polymerization. Then active species C*-1 gradually changed into active sites C*-2 owing to the reversible adsorption of the by-product diisobutylaluminum chloride (Al(i-Bu)2Cl). C*-2 bearing high steric surrounding environment and high trans-1,4 stersoselectivity gave the formation of trans-1,4 units, thus causing the increase in trans-1,4 contents of polymers during the polymerization process. The ID adsorbed on catalyst surface played great influence on the trans-1,4 stereoselectivity and activity of active species C*-2. Dibutyl phthalate with large molecular size had higher trans-1,4 stereoselectivity and higher M w while lower catalytic activity than that of ethyl benzoate with small molecular size. The introduction of external electron donors during the polymerization process further influenced the trans-1,4 steroeselectivity and activity of catalysts. Appropriate external electron donor (ED-1) can coordinate with active species C*-2 and generate coadsorption with Al(i-Bu)2Cl on the surface of catalyst, leading to the activation of active species C*-2 into active species C*-3 with higher trans-1,4 stereoselectivity. C*-3 gave higher trans-1,4 content of polymers with higher M w. Parallelly, excess addition of external electron donors can also complex with the Ti of active species C*-1 and the adjacent Mg to cause the partial deactivation of Ti species, thus resulting in the decrease in polymerization activity, trans-1,4 content and M w of polymers. The effectiveness of external electron donor on the reversible equilibrium between selective activation and partial deactivation of Ti species significantly relied on the concentration and molecular type of external electron donor. 4 Conclusion Two TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalysts were synthesized by the coadsorption of TiCl4 and ID (EB and DBP) on activated MgCl2 support surface. Internal electron donor EB had higher adsorption ability on catalyst surface (0.66 mmol/(g⋅cat), Cat-1) than that of DBP (0.08 mmol/(g⋅cat), Cat-2). The coordination of EB and DBP with (104) MgCl2 lateral cuts (68%∼86%) obviously prevailed over that with (110) MgCl2 lateral cuts (14%∼32%). In isoprene polymerizations catalyzed by TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalysts in the absence of ED, the polymers obtained in the early stage had low trans-1,4 content and relatively high cis-1,4 content, and then the trans-1,4 content gradually increased while the cis-1,4 content decreased as polymerization time. Cat-1 with EB had lower trans-1,4 stereoselectivity and higher polymerization activity than that of Cat-2 with DBP. When appropriate ED (ED-1 and ED-2, ED/Ti = 0.1∼0.3) were introduced into isoprene polymerizations, the catalytic activity, trans-1,4 content and M w of polymers increased, while excess addition (ED/Ti = 1) caused the decrease in that polymerization behaviors. The balance between activation and deactivation effect of ED significantly relied on the ED type and concentration. At least three types of active species existed in isoprene polymerization using TiCl4/ID/MgCl2-Al(i-Bu)3/ED catalyst system. Active species C*-1 with relatively low steric hindrance and trans-1,4 stereoselectivity were first formed through the reaction of Al(i-Bu)3 and active center precursor TiCl4 coadsorbed with ID, then C*-1 gradually turned into active species C*-2 with high steric hindrance as well as high trans-1,4 stereoselectivity as by-product Al(i-Bu)2Cl reversibly coordinated with C*-1. When ED (alkoxysilanes) were added, the active species C*-2 were further activated and transformed into active species C*-3 with higher trans-1,4 stereoselectivity, while excess introduction caused partial deactivation owing to the ED coordination with the Ti atom of C*-1 as well as the adjacent Mg atom. coredata.dc:description: Two TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts containing ethyl benzoate (EB) and dibutyl phthalate (DBP) as internal electron donors (ID) were prepared for isoprene polymerizations using five kinds of external electron donors (ED) (phenyltrimethoxysilane (ED-1), dicyclopentyl(dimethoxy)silane (ED-2), 2-butyl-2-ethyl-1,3-dimethoxypropane (ED-3), 1,3-dimethoxypropane (ED-4) and di(2-ethylhexyl)phthalate (ED-5)). The structure features of TiCl4/ID/MgCl2 catalysts were characterized and the effect of ID and ED on polymerization behaviors was studied. EB had higher adsorption content on catalyst surface, higher catalytic activity and lower trans-1,4 stereoselectivity than DBP. Appropriate introduction of ED-1 and ED-2, expect ED-3, ED-4 and ED-5, caused the enhancement in polymerization activity and trans-1,4 content, while excess addition led to the deactivation. The effect of ED on equilibrium between selective activation and deactivation of active species significantly relied on the electron donor type and concentration.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of internal and external electron donors on stereospecific polymerization of isoprene with TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts
